Authors:
Siraprapa Saraihom, Donald Y Kobayashi, Pongtharin
Lotrakul, Sehanat Prasongsuk, Douglas E. Eveleigh, Hunsa Punnapayak
Title:
Isolation of a tropical carboxymethylcellulase-producing
Lysobacter enzymogenes from Thailand
Keywords:
carboxymethyl cellulase, bifunctional cellulase,
Chitinolytic bacteria, Lysobacter enzymogenes
Abstract:
Several strains of the soil bacterium Lysobacter have been
isolated from a broad range of geographically distinct habitats in
temperate and sub-tropical climates. To assess the distribution of
Lysobacter spp. displaying lytic enzyme activities in tropical
environments, samples were collected from grass-covered soils in
Thailand. Isolation was based on an enrichment-culture broth
supplemented with colloidal shrimp chitin and selective antimicrobials.
Morphological observation and physiological tests, along with 16S rRNA
sequence analysis, were used to confirm the so-obtained primary
identification. Among 44 chitinolytic bacteria isolated, strain 521
(accession no. NCCB 100553) was identified as Lysobacter enzymogenes.
Zymogram analysis was used to characterize bifunctional
carboxymethylcellulase (CMCase)-chitosanase activity in the crude CMCase
from L. enzymogenes 521. The CMCase nucleotide and the predicted amino
acid sequences derived from the draft genome sequencing were deduced.
Phylogenetic analysis of CMCase gene and multiple alignment of the
deduced amino acid sequence illustrated that the CMCase (Cel8A) from L.
enzymogenes 521 displayed homology to the Family 8 glycoside hydrolases
(GHF-8), and was found to be similar to the bifunctional endoglucanase
(Cel8A) from Lysobacter sp. IB-9374 (98.3%) and to the ÔÅ¢-1,4-glucanase
from L. capsici AZ78 (78.1%). This is the first description of a
tropical strain of L. enzymogenes.
